awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Determining the Impacts of Lacunar-Canalicular Remodeling on Bone Fracture Toughness
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support research to study bone fragility in aging, a major unsolved problem. Over 40 percent of women and 25 percent of men over 60 will experience a fragility fracture. The purpose of this research is to improve our understanding of the origins of bone toughness and to test if the loss of bone toughness is explained by the health of bone cells called osteocytes. Osteocytes are strain-sensing cells embedded in bone.  These cells are interconnected by an expansive porous network. Osteocytes can remove and replace (that is, remodel) bone tissue surrounding this expansive network.  Therefore, osteocytes may have an important but overlooked role in maintaining bone quality, specifically toughness. Because osteocyte health declines in aging and disease, it is important to understand whether interrupting osteocyte health decreases bone toughness. This project will advance the understanding of how, where, and why the osteocyte remodels bone and the impacts of osteocyte bone remodeling on bone toughness. The investigators will recruit and train underrepresented graduate and undergraduate students in the completion of the work. This work will also involve underrepresented undergraduate and high school students in the research and will engage K-12 students and teachers in bone biomechanics and materials science outreach activities. 


This project partners several novel approaches to investigate the impacts of osteocyte lacunar-canalicular remodeling on bone quality and fracture toughness. First, finite element modeling, histology, and histomorphometry will be used to assess the fraction of osteocytes that are remodeling bone tissue and evaluate whether osteocyte bone remodeling is related to bone tissue strain. Second, Auger electron spectroscopy will be used to produce submicron-resolution maps of bone mineral and matrix composition near osteocyte lacunae. Contact resonance atomic force microscopy maps will deliver an assessment of how bone energy dissipation, which determines bone fracture toughness, varies at the submicrometer-scale. Third, a high dietary fat diet will be used as a novel platform to study how lacunar-canicular remodeling affects bone fracture toughness. These models exploit the detrimental effect of fat on osteocyte health to modulate lacunar-canicular remodeling activities. The key outcomes of the project are (1) the number and location of remodeling osteocytes and determination of whether lacunar-canicular remodeling is related to bone tissue strain, (2) bone composition and mechanical properties at a physiologically-relevant resolution near remodeling and non-remodeling osteocytes, and (3) determination of whether lacunar-canicular remodeling beneficially impacts bone fracture toughness.  This project is jointly funded by the Biomechanics and Mechanobiology program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Eating a high-fat diet can lead to obesity, metabolic syndrome, and diabetes. In both humans and animals, this is generally considered detrimental to bone health, as it can be associated with increased fracture risk despite higher bone mineral density. Osteocytes, derived from bone-building osteoblasts, are load-sensing cells found within cortical bone. More recently, it has been discovered that osteocytes can resorb bone—a task traditionally performed by osteoclasts, which originate from a completely different cell lineage. In this study, we developed a high-fat diet model in rats to better understand how such a diet affects bone strength, with a particular focus on osteocyte-mediated bone resorption. Using an outbred (genetically diverse) population of rats, we identified individuals that became obese in response to a high-fat diet and those that remained lean despite consuming the same diet. We hypothesized that obese animals would exhibit different patterns of resorption within the osteocyte lacunae compared to their lean counterparts. In male rats, we found that lean animals had a larger overall skeletal size than obese ones, while both groups had similar skeletal mineral content. This resulted in a higher apparent bone mineral density in obese animals, mirroring what is observed in metabolic syndrome and diabetes. Using femurs from these rats, we created multiscale finite element models to analyze strain distribution at the mid-diaphysis of the femur. These models, representing both obese and lean rats, are used to simulate mid-femur loading. Our co-investigatory team at Montana State University (MSU) is using these models, along with confocal laser scanning microscopy, to study sex differences in osteocyte lacunar-canalicular turnover activity. This work is ongoing. The MSU team is also using these bones to conduct contact-resonance atomic force microscopy, which measures the viscoelastic properties of the bone matrix surrounding the osteocyte lacunar-canalicular system at the submicrometer scale.

Long-chain fatty acids, including omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, are essential nutrients because vertebrates cannot synthesize them, yet they are vital for normal physiology. These fatty acids are found in many cooking oils, such as sunflower and soybean oil, as well as in foods like salmon, avocados, and tree nuts. The effects of these fatty acids on osteoblasts and osteocytes remain unresolved in epidemiological studies. However, we have observed that both osteoblast and osteocyte cell lines are acutely sensitive to alpha-linolenic acid (ALA, an omega-3 fatty acid) and linoleic acid (LA, an omega-6 fatty acid). Specifically, both fatty acids can suppress osteoblast mineralization, and even low doses of ALA are completely toxic to osteocytes. Supporting these findings, the MSU team has shown that a high-fat diet can negatively affect osteocyte viability in vivo using a mouse model. Since these fatty acids are key components of high-fat diets, our data suggest that such diets could lead to osteocyte death in vitro, thereby hindering osteocyte lacunar bone remodeling. Unremodeled bone differs significantly in material properties and viscoelasticity compared to new bone. Thus, osteocyte death could have a profound effect on overall bone mechanical properties with high fat diet consumption. This may help explain the increased fracture risk observed in obese and diabetic patients.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/22/2025
Modified by: Cheryl Lynne Ackert-Bicknell
